Ahlen

This award will support an R&D program leading to large-area multi-wire proportional chambers containing a neutron converter in the form of a thin Li-6 metal foil. The intended goal of the program is to use these new detectors in place of He-3 detectors in Radiation Portal Monitors (RPMs).

The project includes the training of post-docs, graduate and undergraduate students in detector simulation, design, fabrication, and characterization. It will help develop the human capabilities for future development of nuclear detection systems. The proposed detector system could help fill an existing gap in our nation's defense against illicit nuclear materials brought about by the shortage of He-3 for traditional neutron detectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been involved with the development of a new type of neutron detector to be used for Homeland Security. The detector will be able to identify with great sensitivity neutron emitting materials such as plutonium which could be used by terrorists for nuclear weapons. The detector could also identify materials from nuclear power fuel rods, which could be used by terrorists for so-called "dirty bombs." Dangerous materials from nuclear power plants or from casks used to store used fuel rods could leak out of nuclear reactors due to damage cause by earthquakes, tidal waves or other catastrophic incidents. Our detector could be used to identify dangerous areas, and to help with the clean up process.

At the present time most neutron detectors being used for the tasks described above have involved the isotope He-3 for the detection of neutrons. Such material is in short supply, and the production of detectors is being limited by its availability. There is a national and global need for the development of new types of neutron detectors to serve in place of He-3 devices. Our proposed detector would use thin foils of lithium metal enriched in the isotope Li-6. This isotope has a large effective area for capturing neutrons and the resulting decay products can be detected by an array of wires held at high voltage in dry argon gas. Such a device is called a Multi-Wire-Proportional-Chamber (MWPC). Challenges to building such a device include the reactivity of lithium to water, and to various sources of electrical noise that can obscure neutron signals.

We have found that several technologies developed over the past decade have made it possible to build and deploy lithium detectors as cost-effective replacements for He-3 detectors. These include: 1) low-noise, high-gain, low-cost preamplifiers for use in smoke detectors; 2) low-cost production of large quantities of lithium metal foils for use in batteries; and 3) development of gas-tight double-pane windows for energy-efficient building construction. The space between the two glass surfaces is filled with argon due to its low thermal conductivity and the space is kept dry with desiccant to prevent condensation from forming on the glass. Our neutron detector design uses 1) preamplifiers similar to smoke detector preamplifiers; 2) lithium foil made from enriched Li-6 by a company experienced in extruding foils for batteries; and 3) a double plane glass window containing our MWPC with the enriched foil attached to the glass.There are ample quantities of lithium enriched in Li-6 at Oak Ridge National Laboratory that could be used to easily build 10 or more times as many neutron detectors as currently exist in the world.

We have built prototype detectors and have validated their performance with exposure to neutrons from a Cf-252 radioactive source. We are now designing a large scale detector that could be tested in the field. We expect to complete a square meter neutron detector with 20% neutron detection efficiency within two years. Our goal is to develop production techniques that will enable the mass production of such devices for less than $1,000 each, which is considerably less expensive than currently available detectors.

Our activities have a strong educational component. The research has been done with the assistance of more than ten students from Boston University, who have gained valuable training and experience in the field of radiation detection. We have also developed special lab sessions for the a class in the Boston University Honors College. And we have held events at Boston University for local schools to show students how research is done and to show them various types of neutron detectors being used to detect cosmic ray neutrons.
